comment: I got an A in this class, but I have ample experience in the construction field. There's a lot of plan reading. Someone that has never seen some of this stuff will be lost, lost, lost. She is nice, but very demanding. I appreciated that as I am not in school to be babied. That said, for a 2000 class, this is one of the hardest you will ever see.

Too much work for just one class. Lots of homework and her tests are hard. She also picks her favorite students in the class and teaches only that side. The most annoying part is she has this annoying smiley face. If you are trying to register and you see ?staff I?, that is her. do not take her, take another professor.
Extremely hard for what this class is supposed to be (an introductory class to construction management). Lots of busy work and her tests are painstakingly tedious.

It's a 2000 level class worth 2 credit hrs and I have more work in this course than my other 11 hours of classes combined (Wrld Hist, Precalc, CM1000, Engl).  FYI, the workload increases dramatically AFTER the withdraw date. That's when everyone's grade dropped precipitously.  Despite her claims, she DOES NOT cover 50% of what shows up on the tests

She is a nice lady. Just do what she tells you and it will work out in your favor.Also, she does not tell you everything, she makes us research for some of the topics that is given. But overall she prepares you for the next professors.

That first comment was made by the professor herself - OBVIOUSLY.  Don't be fooled.  This class is harder than it really should be.  Some things on the test were not taught in lectures.  She also contradicts the book, and does not tell you until after you get points deducted from your HW.  PS - She so lame for commenting on herself.
Awful!  She is cruel.  She does not teach.  I got a B out of the class but I, as did several others, spent 6-8 hours on the homework assignments.  BE VERY AFRAID!

Kim Thomas, CDT, Assoc. AIA is a professional, yet hip African American professor whos many years in the work force provide her with ample knowledge to use in the classroom. Where the class books lack in information she comes armed with handouts that supplement her teachings. Be prepared to regurgitate her class lectures on the 25 question tests.
